data.title: Support IntelliSense suggestions in debug console

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1
- C# Extension:  [`v1.0.5-rc2`](https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/releases/tag/v1.0.5-rc2)
##### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a .NET Core application
2. Configure debugging
3. Set a breakpoint somewhere in the project
4. Start debugging (F5 etc.)
5. Type in debug console entry field

Expected: Prompts for properties of local variables and other suggestions.
Actual: No suggestions.
##### Notes

Relates to OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode#299

As mentioned in that issue, the ability to expand objects in the debug console output window helps but isn't sufficient. For one thing, method calls aren't supported there.

data.title: [Latest alpha] Having to save twice

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a js or json file
2. Modify something (or just retype something to dirty the file)
3. Save

After saving, the file is still dirty. It looks to be doing some formatting after saving which is dirtying the file again. 

This behavior looks to be introduced in today's alpha only.

data.title: F5 to start debugging not working with Extension debugging
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use yo code to generate a Code extension (Javascript)
2. Open the extension folder
3. Navigate in Explorer to extension.js and open it (you can make changes, but it is not necessary)
4. Press F5

Nothing happens. It works before opening extension.js but after the key just doesn't work to start debugging.

data.title: Add horizontal scroll bar for build messages and in debugger windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1
  - C# extension used in some screen shots below: [`v1.0.5-rc2`](https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/releases/tag/v1.0.5-rc2)
##### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Show Errors and Warnings in a project with a few of each.

or
1. Stop at a breakpoint in a project using long-named classes or with a deeply-nested property hierarchy. 
##### Notes

Highlighting on hover only goes so far in a few more places than #5580 covers...
###### Build messages

Note these messages can only be seen in full affter opening the offending file.
![unwrappederrors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6431421/15157544/f99d0ce0-16a0-11e6-8edc-19a2742ea2c6.png)
###### Call stack at breakpoint

This particular view might be improved if the stack showed `{method}, {namespace-qualified class}` or `{class.method}, {namespace}`.
![unwrappedcallstack](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6431421/15157553/0354c8d6-16a1-11e6-93e5-9da3a69f4365.png)
###### Deeply nested variables

![unwrappedvariables](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6431421/15157557/06ce53ec-16a1-11e6-9ad2-d5f8bd6c529a.png)

data.title: Change All Occurrences on folded/collapsed sections
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise Service Pack 1
  Steps to Reproduce:

VB file type
1. Have some of the target items that would be changed in a section folded/collapsed and not visible
2. Select the keyword and trigger 'Change all Occurrences'
3. Make your change
4. Keyword in the folded section is not changed but instead the new keyword is on the topmost line of the folded/collapsed section

data.title: C++ code folding does properly handle macros that are not fully indented.
Intellisense suggests variable.variable.variable.etc for Javascript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a JavaScript file
2. Type, for example, "console."
3. type con

Intellisense will suggest variable.variable.variable indefinitely for all intellisense suggestions.

data.title: Javascript does weird formats on save
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

For my repro I was working on developing an extension generated by Yo.
1. Open extension.js
2. Delete an ending semi-colon somewhere
3. Save

It removes the extra line spacing between the brackets of the deactivate function at the bottom. It also adjusts the function bracket spacing of the function inside disposable.

![saveformatting](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/15158198/90843910-16a3-11e6-91ba-4c4db83341d3.gif)

data.title: VSCode 1.1.0 doesn't recognize Git installed on OS X

data.body:

1. Have Git version 2.6.2 installed.
2. Open VSCode

data.title: Snippet tabstop order is meaningless.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OSX 10.10.5

The [snippet documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/customization/userdefinedsnippets) implies that $1, $2 will create ordered tabstops, but the tabstops are eventually just ordered based upon which occurred first in the template line.

For example, I'd love a snippet like this for typescript:

``` json
"Typescript Import": {
        "prefix": "tsimp",
        "body": [
            "import { $2 } from '$1';",
            "$3"
        ],
        "description": "Typescript import snippet"
    }
```

to default the starting tabstop position to $1, to let me define the import file. This would give me code completion on the $2, the thing I'm importing. But instead VSCode just starts at $2, then tabs to $1, then to $3.

data.title: Latest update (1.1.0) breaks entire UI.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Alllowed latest version to install
2. Launch VS Code
3. Notice that the entire UI is unusable/black/grey. Only the about box works.

This appears to be a video acceleration issue - moving the window sometimes redraws the UI correctly.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1329239/15150767/8cc36d2a-169c-11e6-96c9-73175194e6e6.png)

data.title: vscode.startDebug api command
data.body:
- [x] any os - **@weinand**

We have exposed `vscode.startDebug` command as an extension API. Verify:
- you can start debugging from an extension by invoking this command 
- you can pass in the name of your configuration in `launch.json` as an argument.
- you can pass the full json object of your configuration as an argument
  - if your json contains a `"noDebug": true` start without debugging is started by vscode

More details: #4615

Dark+ theme

data.title: Test telemetry
data.body:
- [x] @seanmcbreen 

Once again telemetry has undergone some refactorings, esp to fix #1000. The appending of events now happens inside the shared process such that DNS issues don't block the main thread anymore. We should **validate** that
- we still send the common properties, like `isNewSession`, `timestamp` etc etc
- we still send the common properties using the same data types, like `timesincesessionstart` is a number, `timestamp` is a string 
- we don't miss events on shutdown
- we still honour the opt out setting

data.title: Proposal: Ability to avoid certain modules/files/folders during debugging process - "smart code stepping"

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: _1.1.0_
- OS Version: OS X

Could it be possible to blacklist certain modules (let's say given libraries within `node_modules` from showing up during the Step Over / In / Out debugging process?

For example, let's say Library -Z- is a common one through out your Node application, but it's very low-level, it would be incredible to have some sort of Flag to say "Skip during debugging process" for the entire (lets say) folder, that way you could continue (F10 etc) and never end up in those files / locations.

Just an idea, I'm not sure how feasible it is.

data.title: debug: refresh values on doubleclick in the inspection panel and/or increasere responce tollerance of the debugger
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: WIN10 x64
- Node.js 4.4.4

I have a rather complex web-app, heavily reliable on express, mongoose, Q, etc... , thus making input->output chains extremely long from the compiler point of view. so more often than not debugger just gives up on me:
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2016-05/Code_2016-05-10_13-28-41.png) 

And its not like these values are inaccessible - no, I can view them just fine if add them to the watch (but I have to add the explicit path to the primitive value, since anything object-like won't be expandable and I can't do it for every single piece of data) or I can use the console:
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2016-05/Code_2016-05-08_06-50-35.png)
The problem is I have to manually do it. Another way is to `step over` since it would refresh the watchers, but that's not a solution since data can change in this one step or even the debugger can jump out of the context in question.

And moving forward also leads to an another problem: - stepping/resuming will cause an error message.
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2016-05/Code_2016-05-09_09-06-04.png)
or sometimes this
![](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/105338698/ShareX/2016-05/Code_2016-05-09_15-16-06.png)
the funny thing is, I have never experienced an actual decoupling of the debugger from the process - hitting "close" on this message and then repeating the action always resumes the debugging session. The annoying thing is I have to hit "close" twice or even thrice (the message reappears at least once). always. never once. almost every time I `continue` or want to `step into/over` and I have to do it since this message covers the debugger controls. And I can't use the keyboard enter/esc key - I have to grab the mouse, since the errors aren't modular and do not receive focus.

So, for the fist part (<...> for variable values) - **maybe you could implement refreshing mechanic, on doubleclicking on them?**
And for the second part (error messages) - **some sort of option to control over this mysterious "amount of time" the debugger deems as "reasonable"?**

Steps to Reproduce:
yeah, thats a problem, I can't share my project, and I don't know how to forcefully lag the workflow - I tried to build a test case similar to my project, but it seems it is still "lightweight" enough to not cause the mentioned behavior...

thank you.

data.title: Indicate VSCode Version on download page.
data.body: Currently there is no way to find out, which version is offered for download on the website. It would be great if the download page would indicate that in some way (or at lease the downloaded file would have the version in its name). Especially since versions seem out of sync quite regularly for a short period after release, which is annoying because the only way of finding out is to download and install.

data.title: Wrong rpm version
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Fedora 23

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download current rpm from https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760867
2. Try to install (console or gui doesn't matter)

It will not install if vscode 1.0.0 ist already installed because the rpm for 1.10 is also versioned as 1.0.0. 

Workaround before fixed: uninstall vscode 1.0.0 beforehand or use `rpm --force --install`

data.title: Intellisense and code validator in JavaScript broken
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  Version 1.0.0
  Commit fa6d0f03813dfb9df4589c30121e9fcffa8a8ec8
  Date 2016-04-13T14:21:33.326Z
  Shell 0.35.6
  Renderer 45.0.2454.85
  Node 4.1.1
- OS Version:
  Debian Jessie

Steps to Reproduce:
Reproduction might be an issue as it seems to be severely broken in my project. I have added the jsconfig.json into root of my project and it looks like this:

{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "ES6",
        "module": "commonjs"
    },
    "exclude": [
        "node-modules", "bower_components", "dist"
    ]
}

Project basically contains some node.js, some react etc. 

But, the intellisense and all ide features are just broken. No code correction, no intellisense, not with in the file, for example creating a variable with String initializer, like this:

var a = "aaa";

VS Code is not able to recognize the a as a String. So no proposals what so ever when I try to get them show. Also I can write full non sense where ever I want and there are no error or warning markers what so ever. 

Also when I open the VS Code, it will show "Loading..." for a while for things I try to hover but after that, nothing. 

Only "intellisense" autocompletion I get is just autocomplete to words I have used in the same file. Words, no variables of nothing like that, just words. 

Only thing more I can provide is that when I open the developer tools in the VS Code I get this error (repeatedly):

VSCode-linux-x64/resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:91 
[Extension Host] Object
Command: "projectInfo"
message: "Error processing request. Cannot read property 'projectFilename' of undefined."

It also presents itself in threadService.ts:198

As I have tries Googling this, set the project up tens of times and I'm not able to find any help, I'm starting to think that this is bug. Also what ever happens it probably should not brake like this.

If more information or tests are wanted, please contact me.

data.title: Don't accept suggestion on `.`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.4, 64 bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start a TypeScript file
2. Use methods on any kind of object, in my case lodash, which is imported and available globally as `_`
3. type ___ (or however you object is named), than _._ and if there are any suggestion for completion, the suggestion is accepted.

I'm not sure, whether this is a bug or intended behaviour, but it is annoying, that there are additional keys/inputs, which work like `"editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": true`.

data.title: Use native Mac OSX spell check

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Mac OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual Studio Code
2. Open any file that has some spell errors inside its content
3. The app will not highlight spell errors and grammar suggestions
4. It should be highlighted spell errors in red and grammar suggestions in green, that is a native feature of Mac OSX apps

The images below shows the differences between a native Mac OSX application and Visual Studio Code.
- **Mac OSX spell check in native TextEdit app:**
  ![macos-spellcheck-native-textedit-app](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261605/15141241/03ff9e00-1697-11e6-800a-329983b949f0.gif)
- **Visual Studio Code does't show spell errors and grammar suggestions:**
  ![macos-spellcheck-doesn-work-visualstudiocode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261605/15141270/2a020bba-1697-11e6-92b9-1fb8b5714f47.gif)

data.title: Support native text control context menu
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Mac OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual Studio Code
2. Open any file
3. Right click in any word to show the popup menu
4. The native Mac OSX popup menu is replaced by a particular Visual Studio Code menu

However, the operating system native popup usually provides useful things such as spell check. Visual Studio Code popup menu options would be added to the native Mac OSX popup.
The images below shows the differences between a native Mac OSX application and Visual Studio Code.
- **Mac OSX popup menu in native TextEdit app:**
  ![macos-popup-menu-native-textedit-app](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261605/15140797/b153fe5a-1694-11e6-8cb1-e4435d9a7acc.gif)
- **Replaced popup menu in Visual Studio Code:**
  ![macos-popup-menu-visualstudiocode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/261605/15140798/b19e513a-1694-11e6-9e34-ef4b20ecff20.gif)

data.title: Ctrl+U doesn't scroll back to previous cursor position with more than 2 cursors

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Fedora Linux 4.2.3-300.fc23.x86_64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a big file.
2. Select a word, let's say `foo`, using Ctrl+D.
3. Press Ctrl+D again to select another occurrence of `foo`. Let's say the view scrolls to line 100 now.
4. Press Ctrl+D to select a third occurrence of `foo`. Let's say the view scrolls to line 200.
5. Press Ctrl+U.

What happens: The view stays at line 200.

What should happen: It should scroll back to line 100.
